Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: The Roles of Organizational Contextual Factors in Worker Reactions to COVID-19

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: The outbreak of COVID-19 has caused great concerns worldwide. COVID-19 directly affects the physical, financial, and psychological well-being of those who live in close proximity to the outbreak areas. Because of its potential threat to physical health, it has widespread effects on the thought processes and behaviors of the global population. This project seeks to understand the impact of COVID-19 by examining how it affects workers’ perceptions of the health-related threat, their emotional and motivational reactions towards the threat, and their downstream work-related behaviors. This project will analyze workers’ anxiety and desire to make a lasting and meaningful impact to their environment as different reactions towards COVID-19. These reactions, in turn, can lead to different levels of work performance, helping behaviors, and withdrawal from the workplace. Importantly, the project will test if and how the organizational context may play an important role in encouraging effective versus dysfunctional coping among workers when facing threats related to COVID-19. Results from the project will enhance understanding of how workers react to health-related threat information, and how their productivity and well-being may be affected by the information. Results will also equip organizations with knowledge to create a context that will help employees adapt to the threat brought on by COVID-19 or other similar life-threatening crises. More broadly, this project will clarify how organizations and managers can transform negative crises and challenges into opportunities to boost workforce morale and prosocial motivation. <br/><br/>The goal of the proposed research is to understand the impact of COVID-19 among working adults within the context of the pandemic. The project conceptualizes COVID-19 as a salient mortality cue and will analyze individual employees’ adaptive reflection and maladaptive anxiety as responses to this cue. The project will also analyze how reflection may be related to employees’ positive coping behaviors such as productivity and helping, whereas anxiety as a maladaptive reaction may be associated with negative behaviors such as withdrawal. Finally, the project will examine the organizational contextual factors that may exacerbate or ameliorate workers’ reactions towards the threat of COVID-19. The project will consider organizational health climate, ethical leadership, and corporate social responsibility practices as critical factors that may promote the adaptive reactions towards COVID-19. The project will use time-lagged, three-wave surveys to collect data from working adults; structural equation modeling and conditional indirect effect tests will be employed to evaluate research questions. Findings from the project will inform organizational theories related to those involving terror management and generativity.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project is to understand the impact of COVID-19 among working adults beyond the immediate health threat of pandemic. Specifically, we conceptualized COVID-19 as a salient mortality cue, making death more proximal and significant. This mortality cue, in turn, can trigger workers? maladaptive affective and behavioral reactions, such as anxiety and withdrawal. In the meantime, the mortality cue can also trigger workers? adaptive reactions, such as their generative reflection and helping behaviors. We examined individual employees? adaptive reflection and maladaptive death anxiety to the mortality cue of COVID-19. Using a multi-wave survey, we tested how individual employees? exposure to COVID-19 information was related to their subsequent increased anxiety, which in turn was related to their increased withdrawal behavior (e.g., disengagement, absenteeism) at work. Moreover, we tested how the same information exposure was related to employees? generativity-based death reflection, which in turn was related to their increased helping behaviors towards their coworkers. Finally, we examined the organizational contextual factors that moderated workers? reactions towards the threat of COVID-19. Specifically, we considered how organization?s internal and external corporate social responsibility practices as critical factors that may ameliorate the maladaptive, and promote the adaptive reactions towards COVID-19 information exposure.

 

Our results showed that exposure to COVID-19 information served as a mortality cue, making death more salient for the workers. This exposure, in turn, was positively related to workers? death anxiety at time 2, which in turn was related to their increased withdrawal from work at time 3. However, this relationship was attenuated for workers in organizations which engaged in higher levels of internal corporate social responsibility practices, such that these organizations provided tangible and psychosocial support for their workers during the pandemic. Our results also showed that exposure to COVID-19 information was related to workers? increased generativity-based reflection, which oriented workers to think more about how they could make long-lasting contribution to their work and develop meaningful relationships with their coworkers. This reflection in turn was related to workers? increased likelihood to engage in helping behaviors to their coworkers at a later time. Contrary to our expectation, the external corporate social responsibility practices did not moderate the relationship between COVID-19 information exposure with workers? death reflection.

 

Results from our research make important intellectual contribution to the existing theories concerning effects of mortality cues. Specifically, we integrated the Terror Management Theory with Generativity Theory to conceptualize and examine workers? both maladaptive and adaptive reactions at work towards mortality salience, whereas prior research focused primarily on the negative implications of mortality cues on work-related outcomes. Next, we focused on firm-level corporate social responsibility practices as the contextual moderators that have implications for the psychological mechanisms suggested by both Terror Management Theory and Generativity Theory when workers face mortality cues. Such focus has allowed us to move beyond individual differences as the boundary conditions, which tend to be the prior research?s focus. Moreover, this approach allowed us to highlight the importance to consider organizational actions in future research on mortality salience. Finally, we extended the literature concerning possible predictors of workers? death anxiety and death reflection by identifying non-occupational specific environmental cues (i.e., COVID-19 information). Building on prior research that focused on specific occupations (e.g., healthcare workers) and specific personal experiences (e.g., near-death experiences), our research pointed to the importance of understanding how general mortality cues may have implications for work-specific outcomes.

 

Results from our research also have broader impacts and practical implications. First, our results indicated that workers? death-related reactions (i.e., anxiety and reflection) as important pathways through which information exposure to a global health crisis may relate to their subsequent work behaviors. Understanding how death anxiety and death reflection may predict worker behaviors can offer organizations with possible ways to intervene to help reduce the negative effects of the general public crises such as a pandemic. Next, our results concerning the protective effects of the organization?s internal corporate social responsibility practices suggest that offering support and protection to workers during a crisis can not only lead to direct health and safety benefits, but also have indirect downstream effects by helping workers cope better with the negative affect as triggered by the crisis. Finally, our results showed that exposure to mortality cues may have positive effects through the generativity-based reflection. This suggests that organizations may foster more workplace helping behaviors by directly tapping into employees? generative values through internal communication or training. Doing so may also enhance the workers? resilience towards stressors.
